title: Canadian Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) Score
description: The Canadian TIA Score identifies risk of stroke, carotid endarterectomy, or carotid artery stenting within 7 days in patients who experienced TIA symptoms. It incorporates 13 predictive variables from history, physical examination, and testing routinely performed in the emergency department.

parameters.name: first_tia_lifetime
parameters.description: First TIA episode in patient's lifetime

parameters.name: symptoms_ten_minutes
parameters.description: TIA symptoms lasted 10 minutes or longer

parameters.name: history_carotid_stenosis
parameters.description: Known history of carotid artery stenosis

parameters.name: on_antiplatelet_therapy
parameters.description: Patient already on antiplatelet therapy at time of TIA

parameters.name: history_gait_disturbance
parameters.description: History of gait disturbance during the TIA episode

parameters.name: history_unilateral_weakness
parameters.description: History of unilateral weakness during the TIA episode

parameters.name: history_vertigo
parameters.description: History of vertigo during the TIA episode

parameters.name: diastolic_bp_110
parameters.description: Initial triage diastolic blood pressure ≥110 mmHg

parameters.name: dysarthria_aphasia
parameters.description: Presence of dysarthria or aphasia during the TIA episode

parameters.name: atrial_fibrillation_ecg
parameters.description: Atrial fibrillation detected on ECG in the emergency department

parameters.name: infarction_on_ct
parameters.description: Acute infarction visible on CT scan

ranges.interpretation: Low risk of stroke, carotid endarterectomy, or carotid artery stenting within 7 days. Consider discharge home with outpatient follow-up. Routine investigations and specialist referral can be arranged non-urgently.

Medium risk of stroke, carotid endarterectomy, or carotid artery stenting within 7 days. Consider admission or urgent outpatient workup within 24-48 hours. Expedited imaging and specialist consultation recommended.

High risk of stroke, carotid endarterectomy, or carotid artery stenting within 7 days. Recommend admission for monitoring and urgent evaluation. Immediate imaging, specialist consultation, and consideration of antithrombotic therapy indicated.

references: Perry JJ, Sharma M, Sivilotti ML, Sutherland J, Symington C, Worster A, et al. Prospective validation of the ABCD2 score for patients in the emergency department with transient ischemic attack. CMAJ. 2011 Jul 12;183(10):1137-45. doi: 10.1503/cmaj.101668.

Perry JJ, Sivilotti ML, Sutherland J, Hohl CM, Émond M, Calder LA, et al. Validation of the Ottawa Subarachnoid Hemorrhage Rule in patients with acute headache. CMAJ. 2013 Nov 19;185(17):E805-12. doi: 10.1503/cmaj.121745.

Perry JJ, Sharma M, Sivilotti ML, Sutherland J, Worster A, Émond M, et al. A prospective cohort study of patients with transient ischemic attack to identify high-risk clinical characteristics. Stroke. 2014 Jan;45(1):92-100. doi: 10.1161/STROKEAHA.113.003085.
formula: Score = (2 × first_tia_lifetime) + (2 × symptoms_ten_minutes) + (2 × history_carotid_stenosis) + (3 × on_antiplatelet_therapy) + (1 × history_gait_disturbance) + (1 × history_unilateral_weakness) + (-3 × history_vertigo) + (3 × diastolic_bp_110) + (1 × dysarthria_aphasia) + (2 × atrial_fibrillation_ecg) + (1 × infarction_on_ct) + (2 × platelet_count_400) + (3 × glucose_15_mmol)
notes: Use in patients with suspected TIA presenting to the emergency department
More accurate than ABCD² and ABCD²I scores for 7-day stroke risk prediction
Primary outcome: stroke, carotid endarterectomy, or carotid artery stenting within 7 days
Vertigo is the only variable that subtracts points (-3 points)
Based on prospective validation in 8,355 patients across multiple centers
